data.title: Password Validator2
data.solution:
import Data.List
import Data.Char

passWord :: String -> Bool
passWord []  = False
passWord s  = length s >= 8 && length s <= 15 && one
  where one = checkNumber s


checkNumber :: String -> Bool
checkNumber [] = False
checkNumber s  =  b1 && b2 && b3
  where b1 = (or (map (isDigit) s))
        b2 = (or (map (isUpper) s))
        b3 = (and (map (/= ' ') s))
        
getPointsinPass :: String -> Int
getPointsinPass [] = 0
getPointsinPass xs =  p1C*10 + p2c*5 + p3S*25 + p4I*1 
  where p1C = length $ filter (isUpper) ( xs)
        p2c = length $ filter (isLower) ( xs)
        p3S = length $ take (length xs - (length [x | x <- xs, isLetter x || isDigit x])) (sort ( xs))
        p4I = length $ filter (isDigit) ( xs)
        
        

main :: IO ()
main =  do
   
  n <- getLine
  let x = getPointsinPass (filter (/= ' ') n)
  if (passWord n)
  then putStrLn ("True, " ++ show x)
    else putStrLn ("False, " ++ show x)
data.statement:
BjÃ¶rn owns a small company with 6 employees. He has decided to give a gift for the most secure password in the company, given the following rules:

A password [[s]] is valid only if:

- its length is 8 <= [[s]] <= 15
- it contains at least one number
- it contains at least one upper-case character
- it doesn't contain any space

He attributes points to a password as follows and sums up the points:

- each space character gives {{0}} point
- each upper-case character gives {{10}} points
- each lower-case character gives {{5}} points
- each digit gives only {{1}} point
- every other character (like " ! . , & - @) gives {{25}} points.
data.inputDescription: <<Line 1>>: The password string [[s]], which contains only ASCII characters.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Björn owns a small company with 6 employees. He has decided to give a gift for the most secure password in the company, given the following rules:

A password s is valid only if:

- its length is 8 <= s <= 15
- it contains at least one number
- it contains at least one upper-case character
- it doesn't contain any space

He attributes points to a password as follows and sums up the points:

- each space character gives 0 point
- each upper-case character gives 10 points
- each lower-case character gives 5 points
- each digit gives only 1 point
- every other character (like " ! . , & - @) gives 25 points.
Input
Line 1: The password string s, which contains only ASCII characters.
Output
A string valid, points based on the given password, where:

- valid is True or False
- points is an integer that represents the sum of the points of each character in the password
Constraints
Example
Input
BigPassword
Output
False, 65
